Forgot to vote - see my other comment for why this is "C".

Selected Answer: DE
It's D&E

https://williamlam.com/2021/10/quick-deep-dive-into-vsphere-namespace-roles.html

William Lam is never wrong. Available roles for VSphere Namespaces: 

Owner
Can Edit (E)
Can View (D)

A, B, C (Create, Modify, Delete) are not defined roles so should be excluded.

questions.question_text:
An administrator needs to assign access to a vSphere Namespace.

Which two valid roles may be assigned to a user or a group of users? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Review the doc others have listed and remember that they already ask this question earlier in the quiz and D is the same answer they marked correct then.

Selected Answer: D
It's D. Here are the instructions: 

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/vmware-vsphere-with-tanzu/GUID-CF707AE9-7BD7-47BC-AAD7-BCF17DCB640D.html

It's done through the VSphere client which eliminates answers A and B. 

It has nothing to do with NSX, which eliminates C. 

D, the correct process, is all that remains.
D Use the vSphere Client to generate a certificate signing request for the Workload platform MTG certificate.

choices.B: Use the certificate-manager CLI utility to generate a certificate signing request for the Supervisor Cluster API endpoint certificate.
choices.D: Use the vSphere Client to generate a certificate signing request for the Workload platform MTG certificate.
choices.A: Use kubectl to generate a certificate signing request for the Supervisor Cluster API endpoint certificate.
choices.C: Use the vSphere Client to generate a certificate signing request for the NSX Load Balancer certificate.

questions.question_text: How can the vSphere administrator generate a certificate signing request for the Supervisor Cluster API endpoint certificate?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Workload.

Backend and Edge networks are not part of the architecture. Frontend is used for Load Balancing services.

https://blogs.vmware.com/vsphere/2020/10/vsphere-with-tanzu-the-fastest-way-to-deliver-kubernetes-on-vsphere.html

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/vmware-vsphere-with-tanzu/GUID-1E7B905B-2D3E-4E60-9F37-8C0C3D8F7771.html

For a Supervisor Cluster that is configured with the vSphere networking stack, you can provide Layer 2 isolation for your Kubernetes workloads by creating Workload Networks and assigning them to namespaces. Workload Networks provide connectivity to Tanzu Kubernetes clusters in the namespace and are backed by distributed port groups on the switch that is connected to the hosts in the Supervisor Cluster.
A is correct..source: I work for VMware

Selected Answer: A
A. It cannot be any of the other answers!

questions.question_text: On which network are TKG clusters deployed in vSphere with Tanzu when using the vSphere networking stack?
